awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the research activities of Professor Wolfgang Altmannshofer at the University of Cincinnati. 

Particle physics has reached a pivotal point.  The Standard Model of particle physics provides a remarkably successful description of the fundamental building blocks of Nature and the forces acting among them.  The absence of clear experimental evidence thus far for physics beyond the Standard Model challenges the idea of "naturalness" as the guiding principle in the search for new physics. It is therefore becoming more and more crucial to broadly explore new regimes of physics beyond the Standard Model.  The research of Professor Altmannshofer will serve the national interest by advancing our understanding of the basic building blocks of matter and their interactions.  In particular, his research aims to address the following fundamental questions:  Is the Higgs boson the origin of mass of all the known elementary matter particles?  Are there new fundamental forces among elementary particles beyond the strong, the weak, and the electromagnetic interactions?  Do elementary matter particles posses characteristic properties other than their mass and interactions that allow us to distinguish them?  As part of the proposed program, Professor Altmannshofer will also strengthen and extend the existing particle-physics outreach program at the Physics Department of the University of Cincinnati.  Students and teachers from local high schools will be invited to the department to participate in hands-on activities and to learn about the latest cutting-edge developments in particle physics.
 
More technically, Professor Altmannshofer will construct and classify novel frameworks of mass generation for the light quarks and leptons and identify their characteristic signatures at high-energy and high-intensity experiments.  He will also develop new ways to search for feeble interactions among leptons and neutrinos at current and future neutrino facilities at Fermilab.  Furthermore, he will develop sophisticated methods to search for new sources of flavor and CP violation using rare b hadron decays that largely eliminate hadronic uncertainties.  Without such methods, the new physics sensitivity of rare b decays is limited by poorly understood hadronic contributions, and current hints for anomalies in the rare b decay data cannot be clarified.  Professor Altmannshofer's research program will provide several new and improved search strategies for physics beyond the Standard Model that are critical in enhancing the prospects for discovery at the energy and intensity frontiers.

por.por_cntn:
This NSF grant supported the research program of principal investigator Wolfgang Altmannshofer. The research was conducted in collaboration with post-docs, graduate and undergraduate students and explored answers to several long-standing questions in particle physics: Does the Higgs boson give mass to all Standard Model particles, or are there new sources of electro-weak symmetry breaking beyond the Higgs? Are all low energy flavor processes accurately described by Standard Model physics, or are there new sources of flavor and CP violation? Does the Standard Model gauge group describe all interactions at accessible scales, or are there additional feeble interactions among charged leptons and neutrinos?

The research resulted in three major outcomes:
(1) Alternative frameworks of mass generation for the light quarks and leptons have been constructed and classified. The framework of ``flavorful'' two Higgs doublet models has been developed, and its viability in view of existing constraints from Higgs signal strength measurements at the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) has been established. Its characteristic signatures at high-energy and high-intensity experiments have been identified. Searches for flavorful Higgs bosons at the LHC have been motivated.
(2) Advanced analysis methods to search for new sources of flavor and CP violation in rare hadron decays have been developed. The analysis methods have been applied to the ever increasing amount of data on rare b hadron decays that shows discrepancies compared to Standard Model predictions. The performed studies have sharpened the case for new physics in rare b decays and constitute the foundation of a vast amount of work that aims to build new physics models explaining the discrepancies.
(3) New ways to search for feeble interactions among leptons and neutrinos at the Deep Underground Neutrino Experiment (DUNE) at Fermilab have been developed. In particular, an analysis strategy has been designed for the DUNE near detector to search for muonic neutrino tridents, i.e. di-muon pairs that are produced in the scattering of neutrinos on nuclei. We showed that the DUNE experiment has sensitivity to motivated new physics models with new muonic interactions, thus extending the physics case of DUNE. As a byproduct, a new Monte Carlo tool to generate neutrino trident events has been made publicly available.

Regarding broader impacts, throughout the project, the principal investigator mentored several junior researchers at the undergraduate, graduate, and post-doc level. In particular, two undergraduate students made important contributions to the development of Monte Carlo tools that were part of the research project. The exploration of the flavorful two Higgs doublet model framework became the thesis topic of the principal investigator's first graduate student who obtained his Ph.D. during the final year of this project.
